intro: Phaenopyrum cordatum, commonly known as the heartleaf sandmat, is a perennial flowering plant native to the southwestern United States and northern Mexico. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, which includes carrots and parsley, and is characterized by its aromatic foliage. The plant features basal leaves that are heart-shaped and covered in fine hairs, and it produces small, white to yellowish flowers in umbel-like clusters. It thrives in arid and semi-arid environments, often growing in sandy or rocky soils. Due to its ornamental value and drought tolerance, it is sometimes cultivated in xeriscaped gardens.
